channel.title: StringWrapper
channel.description:
Well, I've been experimenting lately and am having a few problems with StringWrapper fields.
Now, iirc, a StringWrapper (or RSString) type is, basically, a glorified byte[]. Yes, I know there is more to it.
My issue is trying to reflect one. I'm working on reflecting a [b]static[/b] StringWrapper and converting it to a byte[] so we can get the text. I first tried the simple code I would use for any static field:
[code]String value = stringWrapperField.get(null).toString();[/code]
This however, throws an exception known as "dj". Now this, obviously, is a class in the client. Upon investigation, I have come to the conclusion that the class "dj" handles exceptions specific to their StringWrapper class (and maybe other classes?).
Anywho, I was unable to ascertain why my error was occurring.
So, I tried some different code.
[code]Object value = ((Object) stringWrapperField.get(null)).toString();[/code]
Which, posed the exact same error.
In a mad fit, I tried the last thing I could think of.
[code]byte[] valuez = ((byte[]) stringWrapperField.get(null)); String value = new String(valuez);[/code]
Which posed an error that type "dh" (or whatever the StringWrapper class is...cant remember) can't be casted to B[ (which, as you know, is byte[]).
So, I have exhausted everything I can think of, so I figured my best bet was to post about it and hope someone else has had some experience with this.

item.title: StringWrapper
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

i talked to you for about an hour on msn the night before posting this explaining exactly how to do it :s

granted, i gave no code examples, but i told you concept, i think you struggle with the ideas/concepts of the whole thing imo.

also, dont cast

use: Field stringField; Object stringInstance = stringField.get(null); Field byteField = stringField.getDeclaringClass().getDeclaredField("byteArray"); //replace byteArray with the field name for byte[] within string class Object arrayObject = byteField.getObject(stringInstance); byte[] array = new byte[Array.getLength(arrayObject)]; for(int i = 0; i < array.length; ++i) array[i] = Array.getByte(arrayObject, i); String output = new String(array);

then no loss, and makes more sence.

Read full topic

item.title: StringWrapper
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:16, topic:229727”][quote author=the bank link=topic=302296.msg2428576#msg2428576 date=1220736672]
Yes, a static variable or method is a variable or method which is not attached to a single object, but rather the class as a whole.

So, via static variables, there is no need to create a new instance of the class to access them.

What I am saying is that if the argument is ignored, what is the point of putting one in? And regardless, would it not still throw a ClassCast exception as df is still not castable to byte[]…
[/quote]
If you get that cast exception, then you don’t get the byte array.

Field someStringField;
Object baO = someStringField.getDeclaringClass().getDeclaredField("byteArrayName").get(someStringField.get(null));
String s = new String((byte[]) baO);

It should work something like this.
You have a string field. From that field you get the byteArray.

(Untested and just created by looking at the docs for a second…)[/quote]Yes, because although the StringWrapper is static, the bytes in the byte[] might not be.

Frank_ and speljohan helped me with this last night so I know the answer.

Thanks everyone.

Read full topic

item.title: StringWrapper
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:15, topic:229727”]Yes, a static variable or method is a variable or method which is not attached to a single object, but rather the class as a whole.

So, via static variables, there is no need to create a new instance of the class to access them.

What I am saying is that if the argument is ignored, what is the point of putting one in? And regardless, would it not still throw a ClassCast exception as df is still not castable to byte[]…[/quote]
If you get that cast exception, then you don’t get the byte array.

Field someStringField;
Object baO = someStringField.getDeclaringClass().getDeclaredField("byteArrayName").get(someStringField.get(null));
String s = new String((byte[]) baO);

It should work something like this.
You have a string field. From that field you get the byteArray.

(Untested and just created by looking at the docs for a second…)

Read full topic

item.title: StringWrapper
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:14, topic:229727”][quote author=the bank link=topic=302296.msg2428566#msg2428566 date=1220735892]

[quote author=frank_ link=topic=302296.msg2428557#msg2428557 date=1220735640]
you dont need to fkn paste the documentation, anyone interested will know where to find it, just give a link

yes, if the field is static the object you pass is ignored, it says so right there in the docs

the object you pass will be a field of some other class, that may or may not be static
[/quote]But what is the point of passing anything at all if the field is static?

rsStringField.get(null);Should return the value for the field as long as it is static.
[/quote]do you even know what static does? srsly[/quote]Yes, a static variable or method is a variable or method which is not attached to a single object, but rather the class as a whole.

So, via static variables, there is no need to create a new instance of the class to access them.

What I am saying is that if the argument is ignored, what is the point of putting one in? And regardless, would it not still throw a ClassCast exception as df is still not castable to byte[]…

item.title: StringWrapper
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

Well first of all, I’m sorry if I offended you at all. I’ve just been kind of frusturated with this all, and I have a bunch of school work piling up which i am also trying to keep ahold of over this weekend. Sorry.

Anyways, the documentation is actually a little vague on this subject. Unless I’m just an idiot and don’t know how to read it.

get

public Object get(Object obj)
throws IllegalArgumentException,
IllegalAccessException

Returns the value of the field represented by this Field, on the specified object. The value is automatically wrapped in an object if it has a primitive type.

The underlying field's value is obtained as follows:

If the underlying field is a static field, the obj argument is ignored; it may be null.

Otherwise, the underlying field is an instance field. If the specified obj argument is null, the method throws a NullPointerException. If the specified object is not an instance of the class or interface declaring the underlying field, the method throws an IllegalArgumentException.

If this Field object enforces Java language access control, and the underlying field is inaccessible, the method throws an IllegalAccessException. If the underlying field is static, the class that declared the field is initialized if it has not already been initialized.

Otherwise, the value is retrieved from the underlying instance or static field. If the field has a primitive type, the value is wrapped in an object before being returned, otherwise it is returned as is.

If the field is hidden in the type of obj, the field's value is obtained according to the preceding rules.

Parameters:
    obj - object from which the represented field's value is to be extracted 
Returns:
    the value of the represented field in object obj; primitive values are wrapped in an appropriate object before being returned</blockquote>

The interesting thing is, the field I am working with is a static field. So the argument is ignored anyways.

Read full topic

item.title: StringWrapper
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:9, topic:229727”]frank_, what I was refering to is the fact that your code won’t work either as it throws a ClassCastException stating that the type “df” (which is the rsstring class), can not be cast to a b[ (a byte[]).[/quote]i assumed Field.get(Object) took the owning class as the argument, that said i didnt read the documentation and i havent used reflection for ages

…which is how it works, if i have to actually write the code and test it to prove you wrong, im going to be a very unhappy person

Read full topic

If you look at the code, that throws a new RuntimeException (or apparently the client’s class which extends RuntimeException).[/quote]that isnt even what he was trying to do, hes retarded

item.description:
@frank wrote:

you obviously still do not know how to use reflection… and it doesnt wrap a string, it is a string

Field theByteField = TheFknClass.class.getField("whateverthehellitis"); TheFknClass someString = whateverTheRefIsCalled; byte[] theBytes = (byte[])theByteField.get(someString);

ps, please dont act as though you know what you are talking about, if it happens again i will have to kill you
